TEXT: The applicant , Toviy PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , ORG at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant 's house is situated on a steep bank of LOC . The only public driveway to his house goes along the river , in a land - slide area . The road is quite narrow and it is locked between the riverside and the land of the applicant 's neighbour , PERSON

In DATE PERSON built a garage . The garage went beyond the boundaries of her land and entrenched on the road . As a result , PERSON was subjected to an administrative fine for unauthorised construction . However , in DATE the local council decided to regularise the existing situation and proposed PERSON to lease the territory under the garage from the council .

On an unspecified day in DATE the applicant brought court proceedings against PERSON and the local council claiming that the garage was built in breach of the domestic city planning regulations . The applicant also alleged that that the garage hindered access to his land by car .
On DATE ORG took the decision in the applicant 's favour . On DATE the ORG quashed this decision and remitted the case for a fresh examination .

On DATE ORG found in the applicant 's favour . The court held that the garage had been built without due permission of the city administration and exceeded the boundaries of PERSON land . The court , referring to an expert report of CARDINAL DATE , also held that the access to the applicant 's land had been seriously hindered by the garage . The court ordered PERSON to remove the garage and pay damages to the applicant in the amount of MONEY ( ORG ) . No appeal followed , and the decision became final .

In DATE the court bailiffs recovered RUR CARDINAL from PERSON The applicant received RUR CARDINAL of this sum , the rest being withheld by the bailiffs as an enforcement fee . The court decision ordering PERSON to remove the garage remained unexecuted .
On DATE the city administration legalised the garage by delivering a building permit to PERSON and annexing the parcel under the garage to Ms PERSON 's land .

On an unspecified date Ms. PERSON brought new court proceedings against the applicant seeking to re - open the case “ due to the discovery of new facts ” . According to PERSON , shortly after DATE ( that is the date of the first court decision ) she learned that a geodesic research had been carried out by the city planning authority . This research had shown that due to a long - distance power line running over PERSON land , it had been impossible to build a garage otherwise than exceeding the boundaries of the plot . Consequently , in DATE the boundaries of Ms K. 's land were delimited anew . An expert report drawn on DATE confirmed that the garage was now located on Ms K. 's land .

On DATE ORG granted the application for re - opening having applied LAW . On DATE the court rendered a new judgment in this case . The court established that at the moment of the examination of the applicant 's case it had not been aware of the findings of the expert report of DATE . The court noted that the second report was more “ credible ” than the initial report of CARDINAL DATE , referred to by the court in its decision of CARDINAL DATE . The court further noted that the plaintiff , PERSON , had presented documents entitling her to the land under the garage . On this ground the court dismissed the applicant 's initial claims and awarded PERSON damages in the amount of CARDINAL ORG . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant 's appeal against this decision .

On DATE ORG awarded to PERSON ORG as compensation for the money recovered from her pursuant to the court decision of CARDINAL DATE . It appears that this decision was not appealed to the second instance court .

In DATE , upon the applicant 's request , the regional prosecutor brought an extraordinary appeal against the decision of DATE . On DATE the Presidium of the Krasnodar Regional Court quashed the challenged decision stating that the circumstances adduced by ORG as “ newly discovered ” should not have led to revision of the initial court decision of CARDINAL DATE . The court also discovered certain defects in the proceedings before ORG . As a result , the case was remitted to the first instance court .

On DATE ORG decided that the decision of CARDINAL DATE in the applicant 's favour should remain in force . The court found , in particular , that the authorisation to build garage delivered to PERSON by competent authorities in DATE did not constitute a “ newly discovered circumstance ” calling for revision of the court decision . On DATE this decision was upheld by ORG .

PERSON brought new court proceedings against the local council claiming to recognise her property rights to the garage . On DATE ORG satisfied her claims declaring that the garage was PERSON property . The court also ordered inscription of the garage in the land registry . The applicant did not participate in these proceedings .

According to LAW to discovery of substantial circumstances which were not and could not have been known to the person who applies for a review . Pursuant to LAW , the decision of the court to re - open the proceedings on this ground is not subject to appeal .
For relevant provisions of the NORP law on the supervisory review procedure see ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § DATE , ORG CARDINALX.
